advice: Try taking a warm bath or shower before bed. This might encourage beneficial temperature changes in your body.
Avoid eating too late in the day. This will ensure that your body has plenty of time to digest your last meal.
Exercising is crucial to hormone regulation, increasing levels of serotonin and decreasing cortisol.
It is highly recommended that you stop using electronic devices at least thirty minutes before bed.
Aromatherapy can improve sleep quality. The use of an oil diffuser, with scents such as lavender and peppermint, have proved successful.
Consider reducing your caffeine intake to minimize the dependancy cycle. Use decaf coffee if you would still like to enjoy the taste.
Mild dehydration can often lead to fatigue, so make sure to drink plenty of water throughout the day.
Try to set aside some personal time throughout the week just to relax. A hectic work or social life is not always sustainable.
Eat smaller meals, more frequently, to maintain a steady blood sugar level. Helping you avoid feeling sluggish after those large meals.
Physical activity will not only promote better sleep but can also reduce stress levels. Two major factors in combatting fatigue.
Practice mindfulness or meditation, even for very short periods. This can help to boost your mood and reduce feelings of anxiety.
Use deep breathing when you are feeling stressed. Inhale through the nose slowly, hold for a few seconds, and exhale slowly through the mouth.
Spend some time in nature if possible. Parks, forests, and gardens, can all improve mental well-being.
Cuddling has been shown to be highly effective in reducing stress. A loved one, pet, or teddy bear, can all help us release oxytocin.
Self-criticism and self-doubt will only fuel your stress. Try to start developing positive self-talk.
Always ensure that you are warming up appropriately before exercise. Increasing muscle temperature is crucial to optimal performance.
Daily mobility and stretching exercises are very important. Focus on the major joints; ankles, hips, and shoulders.
Foam rolling or massages will promote myofascial release. Loosening up restricted movements and reducing pain.
Avoid sitting for extended periods of time. Try to get up and move for one or two minutes every half hour.
Have a soak in the bath using epsom salts. Magnesium is absorbed through the skin, relaxing the muscles.
Set yourself some goals that are specific, measurable, and achievable. This will provide you with a 'why' to focus on.
Do something. It doesn't matter how small or menial the task is, like doing the dishes. You need to get the ball rolling.
Find somebody to hold you accountable. Having somebody to pick you up on those down days can be a huge help.
Build yourself an upbeat music playlist. Listen to it when you're showering, commuting, or working out.
Practice grattitude by journalling or saying outloud some things that you are grateful for each morning.
